https://t.co/6MflZaG7wk Finally, before anyone's expectations are raised, this is part of a short paper so I will be limiting my analysis to post primary for reasons of time&space&will largely focus on the LC for now but I'm hopeful this is something I can expand in future.

I've consulted the History Curriculum document: https://t.co/eMwz0YS0VH and some past papers: https://t.co/VSAGZUPjoW but do please forward any other useful documents. I see Examiners' Reports for the 2011 but can't seem to find later versions, is this the case? Link follows:

... I'm interested to know what the uptake is of the topics for study (Early Modern, 1492-1815; Later Modern, 1815-1993) and within these, which topics are being chosen? To what extent are students studying beyond a select few well worn topics.

... how this actually works on the ground for teachers in the classroom. How much freedom of movement do you have within the curriculum, what text books are being used for JC and LC classes and what eras/areas do they cover. I've read the LC syllabus but, like the old one ...

... and what Irish history is taught. Up to the early 2006, the vast majority of Leaving Cert pupils studied Irish and European history 1870-1970. How has this curriculum been updated? Specifically, I'm interested to learn how the LC curriculum has been updated and ...

Thanks everyone for your replies both here and in DMs. I'll be replying individually now. Specifically, I'm interested in the focus of the curriculum as I'm not familiar with revisions to it in the last 15 years. I'm interested to see what non-Irish history is taught... ctd below

#twitterstorians, Iâ€™m writing a piece at the moment about the teaching of history in Ireland and Iâ€™d really like to include perspectives from post-primary teachers about the curriculum etc. If you or someone you know would be interested in sharing their views just drop me a DM. https://t.co/ike98Oq0SA
